text: Family Member: Hi. Nice to see you. Doctor: So, you know, you done good. Family Member: It got better. Doctor: How about that? Family Member: Good news. No new treatments. Doctor: Yeah. I think you get a break for six weeks until I torture you with that, I mean help you, again. Family Member: What’s that going to involve? Patient: What’s going to happen in six weeks? Doctor: Nothing. I just want to make sure your PSA isn’t like skyrocketing. (Door sound) Patient: Oh. Doctor: You know? Ten, ten is okay. Patient: Oh, ten isn’t climbing?

text: Family Member: Yes. It’s a small dose. Doctor: It’s a small, it’s relatively, it’s enough that, you know, it’s going to probably, well, depends. Some people don’t, some people actually even a little dose, they feel, some people feel like really good on it. They feel like they have more energy. Patient: Right. Doctor: Some people just feel weird. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But it’s enough, a small enough dose, that you probably won’t notice it, but. Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, but hormone therapy, uh as far as I’m concerned, it’s the worst part of the whole thing, right. It’s gonna put you into menopause, it stills your sex drive, it gives you hot flashes, and it slows your metabolism by you know twenty-five percent, so you have to decrease your calorie intake. And you have to exercise like a fiend, or you’re going to get fat, and you don’t want that. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um but the other thing is it just makes you more tired, you know. We’re making you into an eight-year-old guy – Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: -temporarily. Family Member: For two years. Doctor: Yeah. Different people. I’m overstating it a little bit, but people are more tired. And uh, but people are more tired. And, and but if you exercise, it’s not as bad. Patient: Right. Doctor: And you don’t have the side effects of an increased heart attack risk. You don’t have, your bones don’t get soft, your muscles don’t go weak; you know exercise is the key here. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: Um, but um some guys have bad hot flashes. And some guys get depressed because their metabolism down. Um, but make no mistake, people keep working; they keep enjoying life; they’re just more tired. Family Member: Uh hum.

text: Family Member: So it has pretty good results in Germany? Doctor: And so what they’ve done different than we do here is they report it on their experience. So they’re like we treated these six-hundred people, people with different stage, and different things, and they try to give some data about how the people live, what was their survival, and they showed you know tumor shrinking, and their response rate. And so overall that Gestalt, that’s a German word. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: That looks, looks really good, I think. And then they collaborate with this gentleman that I have experience with in Turkey, seeing the data presented. I mean you share but you know some of the data that shows incredible responses to these. So I think part of it depends on how active your cancer is for this study, for this, this for the PSMA. Patient: Okay. Okay. Family Member: And then if you see the result, you would know probably in two months if you saw the results? Doctor: Yes. Family Member: And then if you didn’t see results, would you go to a bone marrow? Patient: Right. Doctor: Well, we could do chemotherapy still. We could do a trial of chemotherapy. Uh you know the bone marrow transplant to me, you know, it’s a trial that I’m doing. You know it’s the only treatment I know of that cures cancer. So if you take people with bad leukemia and bad lymphoma you can cure them- Family Member: Um hum. Doctor: by giving them somebody else’s immune system. Family Member: Um hum.

text: Family Member: Monday, the eleventh. HCP Thank you. Doctor: Okay, you did start physical therapy? Patient: Yes. Doctor: How is that going? Is it inducing more pain? text: Patient: It wasn't really great in detail. Doctor: Okay, so this is the, this is the consent form for the MAP trial. So this is the MAP trial phase three, meaning that it's just more advanced and we're comparing it against placebo and it's a large trial. So I want you to take this home, I want you to read it, and I want you to think about it. I'll contact our research nurses too to see if you're eligible. And then we'll give you a call tomorrow and you can tell me. Yes, I think this is reasonable. Let's keep going. You can tell me- Patient: Trust me, I don’t have to wait until next week. Family Member: Trust me, he'll sign it right now. Patient: I’m serious. Family Member: I mean, he's ready to go. We kind of talked about it. Okay. Doctor: You know, so what were the discussion or what were you thinking or what were the discussions that you were having before? Family Member: Well, I was telling him about what N___ did for friend of mine and what he went through Doctor: Mm okay. Family Member: a lot of a prostrate clinical trials study also. Doctor: Oh okay. Family Member: So I went with him. You know, while he started the process, Doctor: Oh okay.

text: Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
